div.p: 1. IV:30. Good Friday Sun rose 5:45
Hiccocks

A man by the name of Hiccocks came to propose that he should brush a wash over all the Gilt-Picture and Looking-glass frames Lamps or indeed any thing Gilt, at 75 Cents or a dollar each— He said it was a Chinese wash, and he had been to China to procure it— The object is to protect the gilding from flies, or from tarnishing— I got rid of him by allowing him to try the experiment of his wash upon the frame of my fathers last Portrait by Stewart. My Son John and W. C. Greenleaf, spent the whole day at Georgetown, engaged upon the inspection and housing of flour— After an interval of 25 days news is at last received from Liverpool—but it comes from Charleston South-Carolina brought by a British vessel which sailed on the 14th. of February— The political intelligence is of an undecided character and so is the commercial— Mrs. Adams and Mary spent this Evening at Mr Frye’s. My composition and my copying occupied the day— The first Stanzas of the fourth Canto of Dermot, were easy, and one of them among the most pleasing to myself in the Poem; but I have now come to one of the most difficult passages of the Story and one Stanza worried me the whole Evening— The constant tension of mind which now engages even my walking hours has already produced a cessation of bodily circulations the effect of which is threatening— I read about half the first Canto of Don Juan; a poem about as licentious as Voltaire’s Pucelle, or La Fontaines Tales— I took a second walk after dinner of about half an hour— Wrote to my Son Charles.
2. V. Saturday— Sun rose 5:44— Fahrenheit 46.
Mrs Frye and Thomas

I walked before Breakfast to Georgetown, and saw the wharves covered with Barrels of flour—thirty thousand of which are said to have been brought down the river and Canal since the opening of the Navigation— Mrs. Frye and her son Thomas dined with us— I drew a check upon the U.S. Branch Bank at Boston for 2000 dollars, deposited at the Branch Bank here and a check for the same in favour of my Son John— Signed also with him a Note to the Union Bank at Georgetown for 5000 dollars at 60 days— The Packet Sylvanus Jenkins arrived at New-York the 31st. of March— Sailed from Liverpool 13. February, one day before the British Ship arrived at Charleston— The information brought by her being of the same character. I finished the fair copy of the second Canto of Dermot; severely labouring upon three or four Stanzas of the fourth— There is an account in Leland of a battle won by Strongbow’s first detachment of Britons by their driving upon the people of Waterford a herd of cattle which they had gathered by foraging parties for their subsistence in the Fort— This incident partaking of the ludicrous appeared proper to be introduced into a burlesque Poem— But the bullocks gored me almost as badly as they did the men of Waterford, and I was finally obliged to drive through them scourge in hand and at the risk of a tossing— I bethought myself of looking into Plutarch’s Life of Pyrrhus for the battle won by him over the Romans by the trampling of his Elephants which might furnish a simile or parallel for the Irish Bulls— I found the incident twice mentioned by Plutarch, but no details and nothing descriptive— So I gave up my Simile but I fell upon another anecdote in the life of Pyrrhus that was so exquisitely ridiculous that I could not resist the temptation of throwing it into a Stanza: though not perceiving that I can any where introduce it into my Tale of Dermot— Mrs Adams went home with Mrs Frye— I finished reading the first Canto of Don Juan— The ton grivois (the English Language has no word to express such ideas,[)] is specially adapted to immorality— Don Juan, is borrowed from the Page of Beaumarchais’s Figaro.
3. IV:30. Easter Sunday— Sun rose 5.43
W. S. and Mrs Smith

Walk to the race ground before breakfast. At the Presbyterian Church, heard Mr Smith from Hebrews 7:26 “For such an high Priest became us, who is holy harmless, undefiled, separate from Sinners, and made higher than the Heavens.” A communion discourse, upon the atonement and far less pleasing to me than the last I had heard from the same person— Solemn nonsense, and inconceivable absurdity— This is the impression, which I never can remove from my mind, when I hear a Calvinistic preacher hammering upon that everlasting anvil of the atonement. “Incredulus adi”— I disbelieve and I hate— It is always to me an admonition of the weakness of the human intellect— That the execution as a malefactor of one person, the Creator of all worlds, eighteen hundred years ago, should have redeemed me, born nearly eighteen Centuries after his death from eternal damnation, is not only too shocking for my belief, but I ask myself what there can be above the level of the beasts which perish, in the animated being that can believe it— A melancholy monument of mental aberration and impotence— Mr Smith’s administration of the Communion was nevertheless solemn and impressive— Members of other Churches were as usual invited—but I did not partake— Not from any scruple of my own; but because disbelieving their creed, sharing the communion with them, might seem to them, either a profession of their faith or an intrusion upon their Solemnities— The ceremony was long, and it was two O’Clock before I got home— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us— Mrs Adams and Mrs Smith, took after dinner a ride to Mr Johnsons at Weston. There came up suddenly a heavy thundergust; followed by rain all the Evening— I added two Stanza’s upon Pyrrhus’s method of curing the Spleen, and laboured all the Evening upon one Stanza of Dermot, without deliverance.
4. IV:15. Monday.

Rain almost the whole Night, and great part of this day— Fog and a Sultry South East wind. I suffered severely with the Tooth-ache, and inflammation of the Cheek— Finished this Morning the versification of the 104th. Psalm—composed in the course of the day seven or eight Stanzas of Dermot—copying also twelve Stanzas of the third Canto— In my walk this Morning I met Judge Cranch who told me that he had prepared a paper upon the Common Law, to be read next Winter at the Columbian Institute, which he proposed to send to me, and requested me to read— I promised to read it attentively. There was further news from Europe, an arrival from Havre accounts from Paris to the 11th of February— A reported Insurrection at Modena in Italy— I read about half the second Canto of Don Juan— The Description of the Shipwreck is terrific— There is in this writer a profusion of thought, beyond every other with whom I ever All his descriptions are minute, much more so than that of any Flemish Painter— And he is equally remarkable in catching the picturesque of natural Scenery of Human Passion and of Sentiment— There is not a nerve, a sinew a capillary tube in the human frame, but he will turn it into a Stanza— And there is a perpetual coniscation of brilliant wit running through the whole— His descriptions of sexual Sensuality, are those of a man meditating upon his own excesses, and supplying so far as he can by Speculation the place of pleasures he can no longer enjoy. The imagination of a Eunuch dwells more and longer upon the material of Love than that of man or woman— It is such a mind too, brutified by the same cause, which could alone give such a description as he does of the Shipwreck— Animal Life and Death is all that he sees or feels— He has no Sentiment but sensuality.
5. IV:30. Tuesday.

There was a very heavy gale of wind in the Night— Almost a hurricane—then it cleared off this morning with a brisk Northwester: blew fresh all day and subsided to a cool calm in the Evening. I was severely suffering all day with a tooth-ache—and swolen right cheek. I visited before dinner Mr Gunnell the dentist, to get him to extract what I took to be a fish bone, and which has been troublesome to me, from a few days after my teeth were last put in order, by a dentist— That is about eighteen Months— Mr Gunnell took it out, but assured me it was not a fish-bone; but an infant tooth— It did not at all relieve my pain, which on the contrary my dinner sharpened beyond any thing I had suffered before. My thorn in the flesh must be pricking me somewhere: and when dislodged from one spot nestles in another— I walked round the Capitol Square before breakfast, and stopp’d at Jonathan Elliots to answer a question in a note received from him but he was gone to market. Dr. Huntt was here with a projection of the intended Rail-road from Baltimore to this City. Mr Polk was here and told me he had been formerly introduced to me by Coll. Chambers the Senator from Maryland. He has resided several years among the Northwestern Indians, and has a Manuscript Volume concerning them which he wishes to publish— He desired me to read it, and if I should approve it to give a recommendatory Certificate to that effect; which I declined in conformity with my established rule— He said he had intended to publish it in this Country by Subscription, but the Booksellers in Philadelphia said such Books would not sell here— But Elliot Cresson was going to England: to embark the 20th. of this Month, and had promised to take the manuscript with him, to offer to publishing Booksellers at London— This was what he wanted the recommendatory certificates for— He had two or three of them which he shewed me— Mr Johnson dined with us. Just before dinner Captain Poussin came to tell me that he had received a Letter from Genl. Bernard at Paris 4 February: He had arrived 31. January and had been received a bras ouverts—by all his old Friends—especially by Genl. La Fayette, who had treated him like a father— Presented him to the King, by whom he had also been treated most kindly— His Letter says there is a very great probability that the affairs of Belgium will give rise to a War. Poussin told me that he came to tell me this because he remembered my Conversation with Genl. Bernard before he embarked for Europe. I received this day a copy of Dr Waterhouse upon Junius and a proof copy from Coll. Thayer at West Point of Gimbrede’s engraving of the last Portrait of my father by Stuart— Began the paraphrase of Psalm. 90.
6. V:15. Wednesday. Sun rose 5:40. Fahrenheit 36
Fendall Philip R.

The Swelling and inflammation of my face continues, with an unceasing dull pain which from time to time sharpens into great severity. It disturbed my rest in the night, and preys on the Spirits in the day, and threatens to arrest my occupations— I walked with my Son over to Georgetown, and visited the wharf and warehouse where the flour is packed up in barrels by hundreds— Mrs. Adams went and dined with her brother at Weston. Mr Fendall was here, and brought me a volume of pamphlets— I was in too much pain for lively conversation— Renewed for 30 days a Note for 3000 dollars at the Union Bank Georgetown— The copying on the 3d. Canto and the composition on the fourth of Dermot continues, and the daily Stanza of versification of the Psalms.
7. IV:15. Thursday. Sun rose 5.39. Fahrenheit 50

Another day of unremitting pain. I had scarcely any sleep in the Night, and rose earlier than usual, because I suffer more in bed than when sitting or standing. The day was beautiful and the weather vernal. In my walk round the Capitol Square, I met Jonathan Elliot, and gave him a verbal answer to a Note received from him a few days since— He is preparing a second Edition of a Collection of the Treaties of the United States, and wishes to annex to it by way of Appendix a Chronological List of Treaties antient and modern— He wrote to enquire of me, whether I knew of any work from which such a List could be extracted— I told him I knew of none except Barbeyracs History of Antient Treaties— And the collection of Martens for a part of the modern Treaties. The New-York Journal of Commerce of the 5th. announces the arrival of a Packet from Liverpool, and of a Vessel from London but the Letters and papers had not been received— John commenced loading with flour for New-York, the Schooner Capitol, Captain Clifford— To take off my attention as much as possible from my pains I fixed it upon the composition of my Poem; but as it draws towards a close the difficulties increase— It laboured much this Evening— I read the 4th. Canto of Don Juan.
8 V. Friday.

A foot bath last Night and a poultice of Elder flowers upon the Cheek, were followed by a Night of tolerable repose, and a morning of relief from the severe pain of tooth-ache which I had been four days suffering. The day was warm and I walk’d before breakfast round the Capitol Square— Judge Cranch called and left with me his paper upon the Common Law, to be read at the next Anniversary of the Columbian Institute; which considering the trifles upon which I am wasting my Time, I felt almost asham’d and unworthy to read— He asked me after reading it, to return it to his House, if I should go this Month for Quincy; he intending to go next Monday to Alexandria where the Circuit Court is to be held for several weeks— Mr Woodsides called again with a mathematical demonstration as he called it of the Quadrature of the Circle— It was however rather arithmetical— He left his demonstration and a diagram with me to examine; and wishes me to give him a certificate, which I shall decline— There is a publication by him in the Intelligencer of this Morning, announcing his discovery and that he has applied through Mr Vaughan and Mr M’Lane for the premium offered by the British Parliament— I am not mathematician enough to know whether he has made any discovery. His problem bears the proof of demonstration to the eye; and it seems to be proved also by his arithmetical proportions; but it does not furnish the length of the side of the square, which would equal in superficial Contents of any given circle— I cannot persuade myself that his proportions if correct should not be already familiarly known to Mathematicians, as I accordingly believe they are— But if they had ever been known to me, I have no remembrance of them— He had also a device for measuring the circumference of a Circle, which was no other than revolving it from any given point upon a level surface— This operation I told him was familiarly known; but that it would not give him his periphery; at which he seemed surpriz’d— I copied nothing of my Poem, much of the day having slipped off in dissipation of Spirits—occasioned partly by the relief from the pressure of pain; partly by the relaxation from intensity of thought upon my poem, which is drawing to a close and partly by the agitating news received by the York Packet, which sailed from Liverpool on the 24th of February, and brings accounts of a state of political convulsion in Paris portentous of War and Revolution— Accounts also affecting the commercial Markets in a manner unexpected and embarrassing— An extraordinary
aspect of the grain and flour markets rapidly and steadily rising throughout Great-Britain, and at the same time falling at Liverpool. This is an Operation of the British Corn Laws of which I was not aware, and has thrown hazards into my undertaking which may terminate in disappointment— I still hold up however in hope. John chartered this day a Schooner called the Delight in Hope, Captain Chase; to take a Cargo of Flour to New-York. This day’s Journal of Commerce brought an account of the decease at New-York of my old friend and Classmate James Lloyd— He had removed about four years since from Boston to Philadelphia—and had been nearly a year at New-York— He died of a consumption.
9. V:30. Saturday
Connell. John

There was a heavy Gale of wind from the North-west all last Night; and it continued to blow a Gale all this day; subsiding this Evening to a clear and sharp frost. W. C. Greenleaf remained at Georgetown last Night in the midst of which, one of the Schooners which he was loading with flour, broke from her Moorings at the wharf, and drifted some ways down the river; to the great and imminent danger both of the Vessel and her Cargo— They took however no material damage— The morning was so cold and blustering that I postponed my walk till an hour before dinner. I then went to Georgetown and on the wharves saw the two Schooners which they were lading: the Capitol, and Delight in Hope. The first was laden ready to sail, and the bill of lading delivered to John and forwarded to W. R. and C. Hitchcock at New-York. On the wharf I saw Mr Kurtz, and the Captains Clifford and Chase— There were several flights of Snow this day— Mr Connell of Philadelphia spent the Evening here. The Commission of Claims against the Danish Government have been this week in Session, and have adjourned till the first week in July. Connell has been here in attendance, and goes to-morrow upon his return— He told me he had bought a place near Wilmington Delaware, where he resides, and had called it Quincy.— I finished this morning the versification of the 90th. Psalm— Finished also the first sketch of my Poem, Dermot, on the Conquest of Ireland; but there are several fillings up to make the plan complete; upon which I was and shall still be for some days occupied— It is a Tale in four Canto’s, of which the design is one and entire— The divisions easily arranged and natural—the Story too strictly conformable to History—the Moral too virtuous for Romance, and now that I have finished it rewards me with a humiliating conviction of that which the Motto of Solon, should have taught me before.
10. V. Sunday. Sun rose 5.34 Fahrenheit 32

A sharp frost which must have destroyed most of the Apricots peaches and cherries in blossom. I attended worship at the Presbyterian Church morning and Evening— Mr Smith’s morning Sermon was from Acts 1.10. [“]And while they looked stedfastly toward heaven as he went up, behold two men stood by them in white apparel; 11. Which also said, ye Men of Galilee, why stand ye gazing up into heaven? this same Jesus, which is taken up from you into Heaven, shall so come in like manner as ye have seen him go into Heaven.”— Mr Smith’s discourse assumed the incident related in this text, as the momentous event which consummated a revolution in the characters of the disciples; which finally removed the delusion under which they had then laboured; first in supposing that the Kingdom of the Messiah was temporal, and secondly, in considering the crucifixion of Jesus as a final annihilation of his Cause.
The discourse was historical, argumentative, descriptive and characteristic—beginning with a Statement of the situation and temper of mind, in which the disciples must have been at that moment—describing the change which this miraculous evanescence must have effected in them, and the irresistible power and energy which they exhibited thenceforth in establishing the cause of Christianity— This is not common place Calvinism— His evening text was from 1. Timothy 1.19 “Holding faith, and a good Conscience; which some having put away concerning faith have made shipwreck.”— This was more doctrinal, and more juvenile; but still not remarkably Sectarian— There was some metaphysical abstraction about Conscience, and knowledge; but no marked allusion, as might have been expected from the text, to other denominations of Christians— Both the Sermons were meditated; but unwritten— Mr Smith is a young man of considerable promise— There was almost the whole of this day a Gale from the Southwest, nearly as violent as that of yesterday from the Northwest— It subsided towards Evening, and return’d again before Midnight from Northwest with rain— I began this Morning the versification of the first Psalm— Wrote perhaps the last Stanza’s of Dermot, but feeling the necessity to keep up the habit of jingling bethought myself of an attempt at the Anapestic measure— For the convenience of having the thoughts provided for me, I took out the Epistle from Penelope to Ulysses in Ovid—but postponed the attempt till to-morrow.
11. V:30. Monday

John and W. C. Greenleaf were employed the whole day, at Georgetown, in despatching the Schooners Capitol, and Delight in Hope, both of which sailed for New-York; and further in partly loading the Schooners Eliza Hand, Phebe and Sarah, and Mina—the former for Boston; the two latter for New-York— They came home late in the Evening— Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us— Mr Woodsides came and discoursed to me again perhaps an hour upon his squaring of the Circle, of which he wished me to give him a Certificate, but I declined. I observed to him it was essentially a matter of demonstration and not of certificate— His method certainly furnished the means of equalizing the given superficial Contents of a Circle by a Square, but I doubted whether it had not been known for ages— It did not solve the old problem of proportion between the Diameter and the surface of a Circle— He himself shewed me a stated problem in one of the Annuals, containing nearly the whole substance of his supposed discovery and which he said had been furnished him by Captain Kearney— And he left with me another of his Diagrams— I copied twelve Stanzas of the 4th. Canto of Dermot—and commenced upon the Translation into Anapaestic verse, of Ovid’s Epistle from Penelope to Ulysses— I found not much difficulty in making the Rhymes; but much in adjusting the measure— The emphatic accent must be upon every third syllable, and there is much less freedom for transposing the accent, than in the trochaic measure where it falls upon every alternate syllable. I am however fully satisfied that this anapaestic measure is incomparably the best for a translation of Ovids Heroids—notwithstanding Pope’s version of the Epistle of Sappho to Phaon— I wove into the fourth Canto of Dermot three Stanzas upon Pyrrhus and his Elephants— In walking before dinner round the Capitol Square, I perceived that I could not compose any considerable Series of lines and retain them as I could with the eight lined Stanza— This brought me to waste two or three hours upon them at home, and I composed in the course of the day 50 lines; being a translation of 35 of those in the original Epistle. To understand many passages of the Epistle, it becomes necessary to recur to Homer’s Iliad— I read Judge Cranch’s paper upon the Common Law.
12. V. Tuesday. Sun rose 5.32. Fahrenheit 32.

Northwest gale— Sharp frost in the Night. Morning before breakfast too cold for walking. When the mind’s free the body’s delicate— Finished the versification of the first Psalm. Composed two Supplementary Stanza to Dermot and translated in Anapaestus 35 lines of the Epistle of Penelope to Ulysses— Read the 10th. Book of Pope’s Iliad, containing the expedition of Ulysses and Diomed in the Night, when they took the horses of Rhesus, and killed him and Dolon— The harmony of Pope’s versification is as enchanting to me as ever—and I now remarked more than ever the power and minuteness of the Poets descriptions— Gibbon quotes the original passage of Homer, where Pandarus violates the truce by shooting an arrow at Menelaüs, and marks the perfection of the picture in the operation of shooting the arrow. This is also one of the most perfect passages in Pope’s translation— But all Homer is the same. The Poet is always a Painter— Every individual in his Poem is a Portrait— You see him—hear him—almost feel him— The art of Pope in giving grace and delicacy to the description of low and vulgar objects surpasses perhaps that of his original— When Ulysses takes the Horses and Chariot of Rhesus, in his haste he forgets the whip, and when returning to the Grecian Camp unstrings at one end his bow, to use it as a substitute— How trivial the incident, yet how graphic—how poetical—that is to say how inventive! I walked over to Georgetown before dinner. John and W. C. Greenleaf came home to dinner, and returned again to Georgetown— They have been loading the Schooners Eliza Hand, Phebe and Sally and Mina, for New-York and Boston— One of them sailed this afternoon.
13. V. Wednesday— Sun rose 5.30. Fahrenheit 32.

Walk this morning to the Race-ground. Began a versification of the third Psalm, and continued the Translation of the Epistle from Penelope to Ulysses in Anapaestic verse. Copied 12 Stanzas of Dermot, and read the destruction of the Suitors in Pope’s Odyssey and the remainder of the 5th. Canto of Don Juan— John with W. C. Greenleaf still busied loading their Schooners— This Evening at half past seven, with Mrs Adams, John and Mary I attended the marriage of Ann M’Knight, with Dr Harvey Klap of Philadelphia— This young Lady who is a niece of the late Commodore Decatur is an acquaintance and friend of my Son John’s wife, and while we were in the Presidents’ House, spent some time with her there— She is an Orphan, and upon this occasion had requested me to perform the Office of the father and to give her away: which I accordingly did. The idea was probably suggested to her, by a few lines, which more than two years since I had at her request written in her Album; and with which she was much pleas’d— I gave her also this Evening a few lines upon her Marriage— The ceremony was performed by Mr Hatch the Minister of the Episcopal Church at the Navy Yard— It was at the Marine Barracks at the Quarters of Captain Twiggs who married a Sister of the bride’s— We met there Commodores Rodgers and Hull—Captain Gordon, Dr Washington and several other Naval Officers Coll. Bomford Mr Lear, B. O. Tayloe—and several Ladies. Rodgers told me that he had been repeatedly upon the point of resigning his Commission so miserably conducted was the Administration of the Navy Department— He assured me that the Secretary had actually resolved to send a frigate into the Pacific Ocean, to pass Cape Horn in the Month of June for the benefit of a Summer Passage, and that he gravely asked an Officer of the Navy, on what part of the Coast of South America, the Island of Barbadoes was situated. The dismission of Bainbridge from the command of the Navy-Yard at Philadelphia was for writing a Letter considered as disrespectful to Amos Kendall the fourth Auditor,
but the measure is now regretted, because it is found to be unpopular. A public dinner is to be given to Bainbridge at Philadelphia to-morrow— We came home between ten and eleven this Evening— Dr and Mrs Klap go for Philadelphia to-morrow Morning.
14. V Thursday Sun rose V.29. Fahrenheit 36

I finished this morning the versification of the 3d Psalm, and the Translation of the Epistle from Penelope to Ulysses, in Anapaestic Verse— I thought of attempting the next Epistle; that of Phyllis to Demophoon, in the Iambic Alexandrine, but found it too sluggish, and determined to try the Ottava Rima Stanza, which did not succeed much better— Copied 12 Stanzas of Dermot, and read a few Stanzas of Don Juan Canto 6. I received a Letter from R. Rush, with his reply to the second number of Britannus— I walked before dinner to the Race-ground, but am unable to compose in the Translation from Ovid, as I could in writing Dermot— I wrote short Letters to Mr Cazenove of Alexandria, to Coll. Thayer Superintendant of the Academy at West Point and to Mr Brigham Secretary of the American Bible Society, at New-York— I had answered last Evening a Letter from George Sullivan, in which he mentioned his apprehensions that Mr Monroe, was rapidly declining in health and would probably not long survive— There was a person named Williams a Cabinet maker who came this morning to solicit a contribution for the Methodist foundery Church in this City. It is perhaps the most numerous Congregation in the place, and the Church was given to them— I declined contributing telling Mr Williams that I thought so large a Society should pay the cost of their own Religious Worship.
15. V. Friday— Sun rose 5:28.

The weather clouded up and rain with Easterly winds came on— I had another application for contribution from the Methodist Church, and this Time it was brought by a woman. I persisted however in declining— Walked to the Race-ground before dinner— Began the versification of the 15th. Psalm, and continued the Translation in Stanzas of Ovid’s Epistle from Phyllis to Demophoon— It is clear that the same measure is not suited to this; and to the Epistle from Penelope to Ulysses— Anxious, tender faithful conjugal affection, full of innocence and naivete is the character of one Burning Passion. Disappointment, Shame and despair of the other— The Stanza might perhaps render both— The Anapestic verse could not express the violent and tragical Passions of Phyllis— I find the Stanza quite unmanageable in this Translation and it wears out my Patience. I read Stanza’s of Don Juan— Couplets of Popes Odyssey; and this Evening several pages of the Tale of Romeus and Juliet, from which Shakespear borrowed his Tragedy— This Poem is nearly as long as the Tragedy, and is written in the Iambic verse of twelve and fourteen syllables to a line intermingled irregularly with each other.
16. IV.30. Saturday— Rain.

I finished this Morning the fair Copy of my Poem of Dermot MacMorrogh, and have now the measure of my own Poetical Power— Beyond this I shall never attain, and now it is an important question whether I should throw this, and almost all the other verses I have ever written into the fire— Hitherto I have confined myself to Translations, and fugitive pieces of a very few Lines or Stanza’s; a small portion of which have been published in Newspapers and Magazines. I have now completed a historical Tale, of upwards of two thousand lines, the subject of my own
Selection— The moral clear and palpable—the characters and incidents strictly historical— The Story complete and entire— It has amused and occupied two Months of my life, and leaves me now like a pleasant dream, to dull and distressing realities— To a sense of wasted Time and to the humiliation of enterprize, ashamed of performance— Yet at the same Time with an insatiate thirst for undertaking again higher and better things. This day we have advices from Europe, by the Ship Hibernia, arrived at New-York, having sailed from Liverpool the 21st. of March— Twenty-five days later than the last arrival. The commercial accounts favourable though still equivocal— I walked before dinner to the Capitol and returned the three books which I had taken out of the Library— I looked into the first Volume of an Ovid Variorum, and to the Epistles with Davidson’s Translation. After dinner I took a second short walk, and in the Evening began a Letter to R. Rush— In driving through the Translation of the Epistle from Phyllis to Demophoon I find it impossible to adhere closely to the Sense— It is paraphrase rather than Translation—
17. V. Sunday.

list.item: Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith

div.p: A beautiful Spring-like day— I attended the morning-Service, at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Smith from Proverbs 3.31. “Envy thou not the oppressor, and choose none of his ways.” Mr Smith’s creed may, and I suppose must be Calvinistic. But that is not the character of his Mind— This discourse was chiefly upon the force of example; and his treatment of his subject was original— There is nothing of Common-Place about him— His Sermon was a short and sensible moral Treatise; argumentative and earnest—without a word upon election, reprobation, atonement or Trinity—and asserting the Liberty of Religious opinions and the adherence exclusively to the Scriptures as a rule of faith, in which the practice of all the Protestant Churches, but especially the Presbyterians is widely variant from their theories— All Creeds are bundles of absurdities; and it is their absurdity alone, which causes the practice of tying men’s minds down to them— Rational Conclusions of mind rest upon their own foundations, and need no buttress to support them— And whenever a Man repeats a formulary of his belief, it must be taken as an act not of his judgment, but of his Will— Walk before Dinner. Mr and Mrs Frye, with their Son Thomas and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us. Finished the versification of the 15th. Psalm— Second copy of Dermot (by Mrs Adams) completed.
18. IV:30 Monday— Sun rose 5.24
Wyer— Edward

I began the versification of the 47th. Psalm— Edward Wyer called and shewed me a Letter from T. Cadwalader of Philadelphia; declaring his present full conviction that he had been in great error in voting for and promoting the Election of General Jackson as President of the United States, and professing to be Penitent therefor— Wyer had put this Letter under cover to Mr Clarke member of the late Congress from Kentucky, to be shewn to Mr Clay— I asked him if he thought he should do this without Cadwalader’s consent— He said no, upon Reflection, and that he would not do it— He said much of the Editor of the Telegraph, Duff Green, who in two successive Papers of the 14th. and 15th has been giving a history of the internal convulsions of the present Administration, which he represents as having arisen from the appointment of John H. Eaton as Secretary of War, and from the influence of his domestic concerns
upon the Government. Green details his own Conversations with the President, with Eaton himself, and with Mr Van Buren in all which he appears to be a primary personage. He alludes in a manner affectedly respectful to the similarity of Jackson’s own case with his wife, with that of Eaton and his— Jackson lived some time in Adultery with his wife; for which her prior husband obtained a regular divorce—but this was nearly forty years ago, and she had lived as Jackson’s wife an inoffensive, amiable and charitable life, and had become quite a pious old woman— In the Presidential Canvass her character and history had been very freely handled; and she died in the very month of his election to the Presidency— Eaton was married to his wife about the same time, he had lived very openly with her during the life of her former husband Timberlake, who was a purser in the Navy; who did not indeed obtain a divorce from his wife, but whose death has been generally attributed to his dishonour— Calhoun—and three members of Jacksons Administration—Ingham, Branch and Berrien would not permit the females of their families to associate with Eaton’s wife, and even Mrs. Donelson, wife to Jackson’s private Secretary, and living in the President’s house did the same— This state of things, produced during the first year of the Administration, Scenes, equally disgusting and ludicrous— Jackson having with all the violence of his temper taken up the cause of Eaton and his wife, as his own— Green now with all his respect for Jackson, and with equally affected veneration for Mrs Jackson, says it was from Sympathy—and that Van Buren became the champion and negotiator for Eaton’s wife, because he was a Widower. He says too that Van Buren took this opportunity to ingratiate himself with Eaton and his wife, and with Jackson, and to kindle Jackson’s jealousies against Calhoun, by making him believe that Calhoun’s moral puritanism against Eaton’s wife, was only a political cant of hypocrisy to head a party against the Administration, and prevent the re-election of Jackson— And hence Green deduces Van-Buren’s conspiracy to destroy the character of Calhoun, and his intrigues with Crawford, Forsyth, Major Lewis, Eaton’s brother in Law, and Chief Clerk, and James A. Hamilton of New-York— Wyer says that a young man named M’lean assists Green in writing these papers; and that he wishes to pay his respects personally to me— I told him I should be glad to see him, but that I should in two or three days leave the City— He said he would call to-morrow— I went with Mrs Adams and dined with her brother at Weston— She took our Grandchild Louisa with her, and we returned home about Sunset.
19. IV:15— Tuesday.

Walk round the Capitol Square before breakfast— Finished with great difficulty and dissatisfaction the Translation of Ovid’s Epistle from Phyllis to Demophoon in the Octave Stanza— A man by the name of Power came with an affecting Story of his penury and want— Living on a small farm four or five Miles distant from the City— Wyer came with the young man named M’lean, who he says is an assistant Editor of the Telegraph— While they were here Mr Hassler came in with the weights which he had borrowed of me— I had called in the morning at the house where he now resides, and asked him to return them— Hassler was so conversible that Wyer and M’lean became tired and went away— Mr Frye was here after dinner, and said he had been told that before the end of this week Mr Van Buren, Secretary of
State, and John H Eaton Secretary of War would resign, and that in their places Edward Livingston would be appointed Secretary of State, and Hugh Lawson White, Secretary of War. Mrs Tudor came in this Evening, and requested me to call over at her house, Mrs Stewart being desirous of seeing me before my departure— I went accordingly; the purpose of both the Ladies was to converse upon the subject of the late William Tudor and my projected biographical notice of him— Late in the Evening Wyer came again, and told me that the four Heads of Departments were to resign to-morrow or the next day; and that besides Livingston and White Louis M’Lane, and Levi Woodbury were to come into the Administration, as Secretaries of the Treasury and of the Navy— M’Lean left with me some English Newspapers. Saturday Evening the 16th. arrived at New-York the George Canning. Sailed from Liverpool 24 March; and brings a mass of political news, of ambiguous character with other advices in no wise flattering.
20. IV:30. Wednesday.

The Globe Newspaper of this Morning contains a Letter from Martin Van Buren Secretary of State to the President, dated the 12th of this Month, tendering the Resignation of his Office, and assigning at some length his reasons for this step— And the answer of the President dated the 12th accepting his Resignation— The Globe further states that the Secretary of War, John H. Eaton, tendered his resignation, on the 7th. which was accepted, and that Samuel D. Ingham, Secretary of the Treasury, and John Branch resigned yesterday—from which it infers that there will be a new organization of the Cabinet— The Telegraph of this Evening says that Ingham and Branch resigned at the request of the President— Wyer and Mr Frye called here this morning; and afterwards M’lean, who told me, what had been hinted to me before by Wyer and also indirectly through Mr Frye; that Duff Green wished to converse with me— I told Mr M’lean, that I was perfectly willing to converse with Mr Green, when he should please. That I intended to leave the City and return to my Residence at Quincy—and should go to-morrow but I should probably be here again early the next Autumn— I found Mr M’lean’s objects were to ascertain, whether Mr Clay would certainly be nominated for the Presidency at the proposed National Republican Meeting at Baltimore next December— I told him I had no doubt he would, though I knew nothing about it— Also whether I should be nominated at the Anti-Masonic Convention next September— I told him I had no communications with the Anti-Masons, and knew nothing of their intentions— He said that if Mr Clay should be nominated Mr Calhoun would not be a Candidate; but if he should not be, Mr Calhoun would be a Candidate, with Mr Ingham as Vice President and that Mr Clays Western friends were very favourably disposed to Mr Calhoun, if they should find the prospects of Mr Clay desperate— He spoke of Duff Green, as being an obstinate and indiscreet man often needing advice and not always disposed to take it— Mr Hawley the Minister called here, to take leave— At five this afternoon Mrs Adams, with our eldest Grand-child Louisa, Mrs Nowlan, Mrs Pitts and John Kirk, left the City, to go as far this Evening as Rossburg—and proceed to-morrow to Baltimore— I am to follow in the Stage to-morrow— I spent this Evening at Mr Frye’s, and met there Captain Kuhn. Began version of Psalm 53.
21. V. Thursday— From Washington to Baltimore.

The National Intelligencer of this Morning besides the Letter of Resignation of the Secretary of State, and the President’s answer, contains also the Letter of John H. Eaton, resigning the Office of Secretary of War, dated the 7th. and the answer of the 8th. accepting his Resignation— The reason assigned by Van-Buren for himself is that he is much against his own Will, a Candidate for the succession to the Presidency, and that a person, bearing such a Relation to the Country, cannot with propriety be a member of the Cabinet— And that he is desirous of setting an example to the Country— The reason assigned by Eaton for himself is, that he accepted his appointment much against his own will, and at the President’s urgent solicitation— That the principles of the Administration being now fully settled and before the People for their judgment, he hopes the President will indulge him in his wish to retire. The President in both instances accedes to the desire of the Candidate for dismission, and there is a very sufficient dose of reciprocal compliments in all the Letters— The Reasons for the Resignation of the two other Secretaries are not given— The rumour is that Berrien the Attorney General has also been requested to resign, and that Barry the Postmaster General offered his resignation, but was prevailed upon by the President to continue in Office— I was occupied all this Morning with preparations for my departure— John’s youngest child has been several days unwell, and Dr Huntt this morning says she has the Meazles. There is an eruption appearing upon her skin— The Stage came for me a quarter past one— Major Poussin came in a few minutes before, and read me part of a Letter he has just received from Genl. Bernard, dated 12. March, totally differing in character from the last, and full of dissatisfaction— He says that La Fayette is cajoled at the Palais Royal, and treated with undisguised contempt by the king’s party elsewhere— That the policy of the present government is to bring things back to their old condition, and that they are in fact no better than when under Louis 16 or Charles 10— He thinks there will be a general War of all Europe against France, and for the restoration of despotism. Bernard says that his own name has been restored upon the rolls of the army, but that he will not re-enter upon the service— He will on the contrary hasten back to this happy Country, where he has already experienced hospitality— The Stage was at the door, and I had no time for conversation with Major Poussin. John and William C. Greenleaf came in from Georgetown and John gave me up the Note of 2000 dollars to the Union Bank at Georgetown, which he had paid this Morning. The Stage stopp’d at Gadsby’s, where E. Wyer put a Letter into my hand, and told me that Philip P. Barbour was to be Attorney-General— There were twelve passengers in the Stage; among which one woman— About 6. Miles short of Baltimore, in crossing a Run, where there was a dilapidated Bridge, the leader horses broke one of the leading bars, and thus broke loose from their traces— While the driver went back to repair his tackle, I walked on, and with two or three of my fellow-passengers was taken up by another Stage, which overtook us, and landed me at the dusk of Evening at Barnum’s Hotel in Baltimore. When my own Stage came in it was found that Mrs Adams’s trunk had been left at Washington— She could not proceed without it, and we are compelled to wait for it here to-morrow. At the entrance of Barnum’s house I met Joseph Gales junr.
returning from Philadelphia, Isaac Munro Editor of the Baltimore Patriot, and Skinner the Postmaster. Gales is going to-morrow Morning for Washington, and took a Letter from Mrs Adams to our Son, desiring that the trunk may be sent on by the Stage to-morrow.
22. V. Friday. Baltimore.

We passed the day at Baltimore—waiting for our Trunk, but were disappointed— It did not come. I wearied away the morning to breakfast time, in Journalizing— Wrote to my Son Charles. Called at Mr Coale the Bookseller’s Shop— He and his Sister and daughter. Mr and Mrs D. Hoffman, Mr and Mrs Newman, Mr and Mrs Barney, Mr W. Patterson, Mr Loman, Mr Joseph Russell of Boston, and a number of other persons paid us morning visits— Mr Newman told me there were many others who would call, but abstained from the fear of being intrusive— I gave no encouragement, to invite visits from Strangers— While I was President it was unavoidable, and the Swarms of Visitors, which flock to a President of the United States wherever he is, are among the heaviest taxes of his Station— They are paid to the Station and not to the man, and each visitor pays it for his own sake and not for that of the person visited— I took a walk with Mrs Adams before dinner, and we spent the Evening with a small company at Mr Newman’s. After returning to our lodgings, Mrs Adams determined to send on John Kirk by the morning Steam-boat, with the Carriage and Horses— The rest of us to remain till Noon, awaiting the chance that our missing Trunk may come by one of the early Stages from Washington— Our arrangements were made accordingly, and I wrote to my Son John intreating him, if the Trunk should not have been forwarded, on his receiving my Letter to send it by one of the two O’Clock Stages.
23. V:15. Saturday.— From Baltimore to Philadelphia—

The weather has threatened to be foul, and the wind has been Northeasterly— Mrs Adams on waking this morning, concluded that it would be best that we should all go by the Morning Boat— I left directions at Barnum’s, to forward our Trunk by the Noon Boat or to-morrow if it should arrive in the course of this day, and we all embarked in the Steam-boat George Washington, which left the wharf at six this Morning— We had the wind and tide against us but reached the Landing at Back Creek about a quarter before Noon— Passed into the Canal Boat, in which our horses and Carriage were cross’d over the Canal— We proceeded in the Boat and came to the landing at Delaware City a Quarter before two— Our horses and Carriage were already on board of the Steam boat Robert Morris, from which we landed at six in the Evening and we came and took Lodgings at the United States Hotel. Hearing that they were full, at the Mansion House. We had not been half an hour here before it set in to rain; and continued to rain heavily the whole Evening. The Passengers who leave Baltimore in the Boat which departs at Noon, land at Philadelphia, between Midnight and two in the Morning—which would have been uncomfortable to us; with danger of taking colds, and other inconveniences in exposing the Child— We had sundry fellow passengers in the Steam-boats, who had some acquaintance with us before; but none whom I remembered— A young Dr Mitchell of Philadelphia with his wife— Mr Poulson, the son, joint Editor of a Newspaper, and a young Mr Gilpin who came only from Newcastle, had conversations with me—also an elderly Quaker, a liberal Trinitarian Clergyman, Mr John Jackson, once of North-Carolina, and young Captain Trippe— At the Delaware City we found Captain Gardner, who came with us as far as Newcastle, and there landed.
24. V.30. Sunday— Philadelphia.

This Morning we received a Trunk from Washington, and afterwards by the Mail, a Letter from my Son John and a Key— The Trunk however which had been left behind was sent on by a Schooner bound to Boston— I wrote and despatched a Letter to John: and I attended public worship, morning and afternoon at the Episcopal Church in Eighth Street and heard Mr Bedell— Prayers were read for the third Sunday after Easter, by another person at the Morning, and yet another at the Evening service— Mr Bedell’s morning text was from Isaiah 28.16. “a sure foundation”—with emphasis upon the word sure, as implying a contrast with a false foundation— This he illustrated by the concluding paragraph of Christ’s Sermon upon the Mount, marking the difference between the House founded upon a Rock, and the house founded upon sand— Mr Bedell told his hearers that he knew the houses of many of them were built upon the sand— That he saw before him many, who he knew were going rapidly to eternal ruin— That his own painful duty was one of destruction—to destroy the false foundation upon which they were placing their reliance, and that his object was to argue the matter with them— The conclusion of course was that the only sure foundation was the atoning blood of the Saviour— His afternoon Sermon was from the Book of Revelations from verse 11 to 15 inclusive, the opening of the Books at the day of Judgment, when the Sea and Death and Hell (or Hades) shall give up their dead—so that the whole human race both in body and Soul shall be there. This was then a discourse upon the Day of Judgment: it was one of a Series; for he gave notice that he had discoursed upon the same text before, and that he should resume the subject again— Indeed the two Sermons of this day were in substance upon one theme— I was on that account less satisfied with them than I should have been, with more of variety— A great part of Mr Bedell’s merit as a preacher is in his delivery— The house though large was crowded, both morning and afternoon; and it was not without difficulty, that I obtained seats; with I know not whom in the morning; and after dinner, in a pew where the books had upon them the name of Newbold— Mr John Vaughan had called upon me this Morning, and offered me a seat at the Unitarian Church, but said Mr Furness was ill and would not preach— I therefore preferr’d hearing Mr Bedell— Between the services we had visits from Mrs J. S. Johnston and Miss Brown, with Mr Gilpin, R. Walsh with his Son, and Mr Wallenstein— After the Evening Service I called at judge Hopkinson’s, and J. Sergeant’s but neither of them was at home— Hopkinson has learnt within a few days the death of his Son Edward who was a Midshipman in the Navy—killed by falling from a-top— The second of his Sons whom he has lost in the Navy: both promising youths— Sergeant soon after I returned to my lodgings, and Mrs Adams went with him to see his wife, who has a daughter three weeks old, and is yet confined to her chamber— I had evening visits from William Lee, Josiah Randall, Dr Heister, Richard Peters, N. Biddle, and Mr Wallenstein, who said he had just received information that he had been appointed Consul General of Russia in Brazil— He has it as yet only in a Letter from Baron Sacken, the Chargé d’Affaires at Washington; but has not received his Commission— He appears not to be pleased with the appointment, though it is promotion— He dreads the excessive heat of the Climate.
25. V. Monday—

I called this morning with Mrs Adams, at Dr. Mease’s; and Miss Mease went with her and visited Mrs Hopkinson; in deep distress at the death of her Son Edward— We had afterwards a number of visitors— Mr and Mrs William Lee— Bishop White and his Son— George and Mrs Harrison, Dr and Mrs Klapp, Miss M’Knight and Lieutenant Chauncey; and some
others. Dr Physick came to see me, and I consulted him concerning the state of my health, which is drooping, and I believe irretrievable— My most distressing complaint at present is the inflammation of my eyes which reduces me to a state of inaction both of body and mind— I gave him an account of my ailment and he gave me his advice— But as I could not conveniently stay here at this time several days, I agreed to pass a week at Philadelphia, if so it please God, on my way to Washington, the next Autumn— The Doctor thought he understood one of my primitive complaints, but he did not approve of the suggestion of Dr. Huntt to open an issue in my knee— He was thunderstruck when I told him I usually took one, sometimes two and occasionally three glasses of Madeira wine after dinner— He advised me to abstain from wine altogether, and from all fermented liquors— Mrs Adams with the family left Philadelphia, at one O’Clock, to go this Evening to lodge at Trenton—and thence proceed to-morrow to Brunswick, where I am to overtake them— I called at the U.S. Bank to see N. Biddle, but he had been called out— I dined with him— Mrs Biddle was present and Dr Chapman, Robert Walsh, and Richard Peters— There is scarcely any other topic of Conversation than the recent breaking up of the President’s Cabinet at Washington— His Correspondence with each of the Ex-Secretaries on this occasion has been given one by one: each day one— Those of the Secretaries of State, and of War were published before I left the City— That with Ingham on Friday, and that with Branch on Saturday— The Letters to the two last were apparently written by Jackson himself, and they afford matter for much amusement. Ingham and Branch were not inclined to resign: and he was not willing to pass for having requested them to resign— He puts it upon the ground that his Cabinet proper was a Unit which had come together in great harmony—and as two individuals of the Unit had voluntarily withdrawn, he thought it necessary to reorganize the whole Cabinet— There was a Caricature published here on Saturday upon this incident, called the Rats leaving a falling house— Four black rats, with faces of recognizable likeness to the four Secretaries are scampering away upon the flour. Jackson is struggling to sustain himself in a Chair that is breaking under him; and his right foot is pressing upon Van-Buren’s tail, as if to detain him— An altar of Reform is falling over, with an imp having the head of an Ass, the body of a monkey, and the wings of a bat, armed with a broom— The room is hung round with Papers on each of which is inscribed Resignation and the President’s spitting box and broken tobacco pipe are on the floor— Two thousand copies of this Print have been sold in Philadelphia this day— Ten thousand Copies were struck off; and will all be disposed of within a fortnight— This is an indication of the estimation in which Jackson and his Administration are held— Not a human being of any party regrets the loss of the Services of any of the Secretaries withdrawn. I spent the Evening at J Sergeant’s. Edward Ingersoll was there.
26. V. Tuesday— From Philadelphia to New-York.

At six this morning I ship’d in the Steam-boat Delaware; met Mr John Vaughan in the Street and he accompanied me to the boat— He gave me two packets, one for Alexander H. and the other for Edward Everett—being diplomas of their Election as members of the American Philosophical Society— There were I believe, not less than four hundred passengers in the Steam-boat; and the deck was encumbered with boxes and bales of merchandize to such a degree that it was scarcely possible to move from one part of it to the other— Of the Passengers, I knew judge Smith of Florida, and his daughter—Mr Hall of Washington who was going to New-York; and Mr Lazell of Bridgwater, a member of the Last House of Representatives in Massachusetts, who took a distinguished part in the debates on the Petition of the grand Lodge at Boston— I had some Conversation with him upon the Subject— He stands the highest on the list of Candidates as a Senator for the County of Plymouth for the present year— None of the Senators’ . . . Candidates in that County, having a majority of votes of the People— We landed at Trenton just before eleven O’Clock, and proceeded immediately in Stages— With my Companions in the Stage I had no acquaintance, and found none of them very agreeable— In four hours we arrived at New-Brunswick, and embarked in the Steam-boat Swan— Mrs Adams and the family, with the horses and Carriage were already on board— Of four Ladies who were in the Stage with me from Trenton, one alighted at Princeton— Of the rest, and of the men who were with them I saw no more after we entered the Steamer at Brunswick— There I met a family of Quakers who cordially greeted me— Judge Bruin of New-Jersey who told me he had been introduced to me at Washington, and a Mr Peugnet a Frenchman, who said he had been presented to me two or three years since by General Bernard— He said he had received a Letter from the General dated the 12th. of March; expressing some discontent with the state of things there—advising him not to return; and mentioning his own intention to embark for this Country the 15th. of April. But Peugnet said he should nevertheless sail in the Packet of the first of May for Havre— We landed at New-York at 6 in the Evening before Sunset, and walking up Broadway met Joseph Blunt— We could not procure convenient lodgings at the City Hotel, and came to Hamilton’s Washington Hotel where we found comfortable accommodation— Mr George Sullivan, who lodges at the same house called for a few minutes in the Evening.
27. V:30. Wednesday— Steam-boat President— Long-Island Sound

We took passage on board the Steam-boat President Captain Bunker for Providence— She was to depart at five in the afternoon, but our Carriage and horses, were embarked at Noon, when the tides was low, and the deck of the vessel on a level with the wharf. I paid a visit to the Ex-President Monroe at the house of his Son in Law Samuel L. Gouverneur— He was confined to his chamber, and extremely feeble and emaciated— Congress passed at their last Session an Act making a further allowance to him for his claims of thirty thousand dollars which have been paid him. He has advertised for Sale his Estate in Loudoun County Virginia, and proposes to go there in a few weeks, but it is doubtful whether he will ever be able to leave his chamber— Mr Monroe is a very remarkable instance of a man whose life has been a continued
Series of the most extraordinary good fortune, who has never met with any known disaster has gone through a splendid Career of public service— Has received more pecuniary reward from the public than any other man since the existence of the Nation; and is now dying at the age of seventy-two in wretchedness and beggary. I sat with him perhaps half an hour. He spoke of the commotions now disturbing Europe, and of the recent Quasi-Revolution at Washington; but his voice was so feeble that he seemed exhausted by the exertion of speaking. I did not protract my visit; and took leave of him in all probability for the last Time— On returning to my lodgings I had a succession of visitors till dinner time— The younger brother of G. C. Verplanck with his Sister—General Morton and his Son—General and Mrs Scott—Mr Maury, heretofore Consul of the United States at Liverpool and his Son; who arrived here two or three days since in the packet which sailed from Liverpool the first of this Month—Mr and Mrs Parish, with Miss Payne Edmund Blunt and Mr Mosquera, an Exile from the Republic of Columbia, of the party opposed to the late General Bolivar—Mr Josiah Quincy junr of Boston, who is here on a tour with his wife for her health—Mr Stephen White, Oliver Wolcott, Mr and Mrs Charles A. Davis were here while we were out and left Cards. General Scott before he paid his visit sent to enquire if it would be agreeable to me to receive it; and I met his advance to reconciliation with cordiality. I received three invitations— One from Mr Hamblin, manager of the Bowery Theatre, to attend this Evening the performance of Richard the third by Booth— One from the National Academy of Design, to view their sixth annual exhibition this day, previous to its opening to the Public: and one from a Committee of Citizens, who give tomorrow a Public Dinner to Gulian C. Verplanck one of the Representatives in Congress from the City of New-York, for his exertions in the cause of Literature— In obtaining at the last Session of Congress a revision and improvement of the Law of Copy-rights. I was prevented by visitors from viewing the Exhibition, and declined the two other invitations— Joseph Blunt dined with us— At 5. we walk’d to the bottom of Courtland Street and embarked in the Steamboat President, Captain Robert S. Bunker; and immediately left the wharf. The morning had been fine, with clear Sun Shine but a chilling Easterly wind. From Noon it had been gradually clouding up; and threatened a Northeast Storm— Mrs Adams was desirous of postponing our departure, and wished me to accept the invitation to Verplanck’s dinner— But I have a strong aversion to postponements of departure, especially for appearances of weather, and never flinch from embarking when my Captain is willing to go— I persisted and we embarked— The storm came on just as we left the wharf; and by the time we came to Sands’s point, and entered Long-Island Sound it blew a heavy gale of wind— The evening was dull and gloomy, and many of the Passengers were sick.
28. VII. Thursday— Stonington Harbour.

The Night was very severe, and the gale violent, but the Moon had only two days passed the full, and it was not very dark. The boat is the finest on the line, and the effect of a Storm upon a Steam-boat is altogether different from that upon a sharp-keeled ship with high masts and Sails— The Steam-boats floats upon the wave like a log— Her pitching and rolling are scarcely perceptible in comparison with the vehement lurches of a ship— The principal dangers of a Steam-boat are to her paddles and her boilers— We had the wind directly ahead; and the Engines being heavily charged with Steam, the Surges came continually in violent shocks upon her bow, every one of which seemed as if it would stave it in; and made the whole body of the boat tremble like a person in a fit of the ague. I slept not a wink the whole Night, but did not rise till seven— Not half the Passengers were at breakfast, and
no Ladies— Our progress in the teeth of the wind was slow— The boat usually performs her passage from New-York to Providence in 15 hours— We had been 17 hours on board, and were barely opposite to New-London— Many of the passengers were alarmed at the Prospect, of passing round Point Judith; and the Captain himself became apprehensive that his fuel, might fall short— His Coal was already nearly exhausted, and his Stock of Wood was quite small. He took the passage through Fisher’s Island Sound, and about eleven in the morning in the midst of a furious squall of wind, and rain came to anchor in the harbour of Stonington— Here we remained the rest of the day, which would scarcely have been tedious to me, but that the inflammation of my eyes would not permit me to read— I made several attempts but was as repeatedly compelled to desist— Separated from my own family, the Ladies being confined to their cabin, I had no fellow passenger of congenial disposition with whom to hold pleasant conversation. There was Lieutenant Governor Collins of Rhode-Island with an infant grand-daughter—a Mr Howard formerly of Providence, but now of Philadelphia, Stephen White and one of his daughters—Thomas H. Perkins junr. and his wife; a Mr Page a relative of Daniel Webster—Edward Payne, one of the twin Sons of the late William Payne, born at New-York in 1804. and many others entirely unknown to me, and whose names I did not ascertain. I found myself as unable to think as to read, and strove in vain to compose a Stanza or even a couplet— I was rather in a humour to commit to the flames every thing that I ever had written in verse or prose— Having passed the last Night without a wink of sleep, I turned into my birth after dinner, and slept about 3 hours till the dusk of Evening, and retired again to bed between nine and ten at Night.
29. V:30. Providence— Dedham.

I had a very good Night’s rest. Dulness always sleeps well. Rose at half past five and found the boat, still in Stonington harbour, and the gale blowing with unabated fury— There was talk among the Passengers that the Captain had concluded to go back to New-London to procure a fresh supply of Coal— At six the Anchor was weighed, and the Boat struck upon the Bar. This delayed us about an hour, and as the tide rose she floated— The Pilot, my old friend Captain Justin took his course towards his Port; at half past ten we doubled Point Judith; reached the harbour of Newport at Noon, and the wharf at Providence three hours later—without accident of harm to the boat or to any one in it. Augustus Thorndike came on board the boat at Newport. At Providence Mrs Adams and the family remained, to come on with the Carriage and Horses. I took a Seat in the Mail Stage as far as Dedham. My fellow passengers were Mr and Miss White; Mr. and Mrs. Perkins, Mr Page, who is the favoured suitor of Miss White, and Mr. Edward Payne. We came at six to Fuller’s at Walpole, and before eight to Dedham— I took leave of my fellow-passengers there and stopp’d at Brides for the Night— The gale had subsided but was not yet over, and I felt a Sentiment of gratitude which I was quite unable to express— I had never experienced a more boisterous time in the Sound, and felt satisfaction in reflection upon my perseverance at New-York in the determination to embark— I had abstained also from using any importunity with the Captain, or obtruding any advice upon the Captain; which Mr. White told me he had done; and as did others of the Passengers— I preferred leaving him to his own Enterprize and discretion— At Dedham on parting from Mr White who was going into Boston, I requested him to send word to my Son Charles, this Evening, that we were all safe arrived, and that he had left me at Dedham—which he promised me he would do.
30. V.15. From Dedham to Quincy.

I took an early breakfast this Morning at Dedham, and then took a horse Chaise and driver who brought me over to Quincy— The wind of the Storm has abated, but there was a remnant of drizzling rain— I reached home at eight O’Clock and found Mrs Kirk who has passed the winter at the House— Began the reading suspended by my departure from Washington—Ezekiel 19— Versified a Stanza of the 23d Psalm—with extreme difficulty— Nothing else— I am utterly unable to comprehend why during the Months of February and March, and until I left Washington, I could write verse almost as easily as prose while I can now scarcely strain from hard bound brains eight lines a day—especially as the rhymes that come the hardest, are the worst— I found here, the only copy extant of the Epistle to my mother, written at Ealing in 1816. I read part of it, and perceived all its platitude— Visited my Garden, and witnessed some of the effects of my labours, the last Season— The severity of the Winter has made considerable destruction of my plants, but has spared more of them than I had expected to live— Of the Downton Strawberry vines, given me, by W. H. Sumner 2. Septr. 1830. there are 16 plants yet alive, and so are three of the five Wild Strawberry plants which I took up in November at the Railway. The weight of the Snow has broken off the double Stem of the finest elm in the Summer house cellar; also the finest horse Chesnut tree; and has made almost all the others crooked. The young trees, which I set out in the garden and nursery are almost all alive: and there are about 150 trees up from the seeds which I sowed last year; chiefly Apples— I dined alone, and after dinner called at my brother’s— Found him and his wife in great distress—both their daughters being ill— Abigail very severely with a bilious fever— Soon after I returned home my Son Charles came in from Boston—and about 6 O’Clock, my wife with our Grand-daughter Louisa, Mrs Nowlan, Mrs Pitts, and John Kirk, arrived with our own Carriage and Horses from Providence, whence they came this morning. I duly felt the blessing of having thus accomplished our journey without evil accident, and arriving all in good health, excepting the affliction of my eyes— Charles returned to Boston. Elijah Spear, called here this afternoon, and spoke of the Necessity of fencing the town-river Salt-marsh lot.

Day. Until our departure from Washington the distribution of my time was of the preceding Months except that after the finishing of Dermot my vein of versification had nearly run out— We have been ten days upon the road; leading an irregular life, as all travellers must do. I pray for the usefulness of the future.
